body:
Comment 2 by **fake.shawn2**: 
That's just not true. I don't know where you got that kind of statement from. Maybe you
are not familiar with many sorting algorithms. A merge sort can work very efficiently on
linked lists; in fact, it can even sort tape drives efficiently:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merge_sort#Merge_sort_using_tape_drives

The C++ standard has a list class (doubly-linked list), which has a .sort() method,
which is guaranteed by the standard to run in O(n log n) time.
